Award.AwardTitle: Interferometric Imaging of Deep Mantle Reflectors Beneath the Western United States
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent seismological investigations of the upper-mantle located directly beneath the western United States have resolved a remarkable degree of structure and heterogeneity. These efforts have revealed previously unknown structures, such as large-scale mantle drips. How these upper-mantle structures are related to structure and processes in the mid- and lower-mantle is currently unresolved. A key step in deciphering this interaction between upper-mantle structures with deeper mantle layers is to use high resolution mapping of seismic discontinuities. In particular, discontinuities located approximately 400 to 700 km in depth (the mantle transition zone) are expected to be strongly affected by their interaction with upper mantle structures and are key target areas being investigated in this study.

This work has developed a new technique based on seismic interferometry to investigate the nature of seismic reflectors in the upper- to mid-mantle region. Seismic processing using an interferometry approach has been extensively utilized in small-scale oil exploration efforts in the last decade, yet has not been applied to deeper targets as techniques of this kind require dense spacing of seismic recorders. Prior to the significant increase in seismic instruments made possible by the USArray project, this technique would not have been possible to adapt.

Past efforts for looking at mantle discontinuity structure have been focused on studying seismic wave reflections off of the underside of seismic discontinuities. Many of these efforts have used underside reflections from the seismic phase SS (termed SS-precursors). However, using SS-precursors presents challenges in determining discontinuity depth, as knowledge of the seismic wave velocity on both the source- and receiver-side of the SS path is needed. The technique used in this study applies cross-correlation interferometry to migrate the SS-precursor data with the direct S-wave arrival passing through the discontinuity. This eliminates the need for detailed velocity structure on both source- and receiver-paths and is not dependent on any prior knowledge of where the seismic source is located. This technique provides better spatial resolution on mantle discontinuity structure and is elucidating the link between upper- and lower-mantle processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this work we have developed new techniques that have
improved the ability to image discontinuities in Earth’s upper mantle (depths
ranging from approximately 250 to 700 km). 
The presence of discontinuity structure in the upper mantle is variable due
to lateral variations in temperature and composition which are related to large
scale tectonic processes.  In order to
decipher what processes are ongoing in the mantle we need to image these
structures better. Much of the previous work has been done using long period
seismic S-wave arrivals that bounce off of the underside of these
discontinuities.  In this project we have
developed methods that allow for enhanced imaging of these structures.



Notably, we have developed a new method for taking long
period wave energy and decomposing the waveforms recorded by seismometers into
a series of spikes.  We call the
technique the Viterbi Sparse Spike Detection (VSSD) technique.  This technique requires two inputs: (1) an
estimate of what the earthquake source time function looks like, and (2) an
estimate of the number of expected seismic arrivals within the time period of
interest.  The technique takes a seismic
recording and returns a series of spikes that gives the most probable
travel-time and amplitude of the arrivals that made up the original seismogram.  The technique is relatively insensitive to
reasonable amounts of noise in the seismogram and errors in the frequency and
phase content of the source estimate.  In
addition it provides robust travel-time and amplitude information when multiple
seismic phases arrive nearly coincidentally causing constructive and
destructive interference.  Because most
imaging techniques depend on stable measurements of the travel-time and
amplitude of seismic arrivals, this method has improved our imaging
capabilities by providing more robust measurements.



We have also further developed the SHaxi method for
simulating seismic waves that interact with upper mantle discontinuity
structure.  The SHaxi technique is
available free for download and is a method that allows us to simulate
earthquake wave motions in the Earth and how these waves interact with Earth
structure.  We have made further
modifications to this method in order to simulate what happens to seismic waves
when they encounter realistic changes in mantle discontinuity structure and
what the ensuing seismic recordings on the surface of the Earth would look
like.  An example of what the seismic
wave field looks like as it interacts with the mantle transition zone (discontinuities
at 410 and 670 km depths) is displayed in the attached figure.  In addition, we have compiled a series of
animations that show the evolution of the seismic wave field from an earthquake
to be used as an educational resource.



We have also imaged an intermittent seismic discontinuity that
exists between in the depth range from 250 to 310 km.  We used seismic recordings from the
Earthscope Transportable Array and Flexible Array experiments.  We found evidence for a discontinuity that
exists beneath the Kurile subduction zone, the Tonga-Fiji subduction region,
and the Nazca subduction zone.  The
presence of a discontinuity at approximately 300 km depth in the vicinity of
subduction zones may be due to the increase of basaltic materials that are
being subducted in these regions.
